posts.name: Tyler Phillips
posts.cooked: I am looking for Solid EVA closed cell foam with density between 4 and 6 lb./ft^3 with a thickness of .5 to make bumpers, we have just been using pool noodles in the past and we are looking to use EVA along with other foams to do this, we are just struggling to find a place to buy these materials. Where do other teams buy this material?

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
Foam Factory in Michigan.  They will ship, but $$

Temu has a decent selection, but it’ll be 1 month ship time.

Foam Order online.

There are many many places that will sell it.  Start searching.

posts.name: Tyler Phillips
posts.cooked: I’m not sure how I missed EVA foam from the foam factory when I was ordering polyethylene from there, thank you!

posts.name: Jim Forbes
posts.cooked:
Late to the show as usual…we discovered at our week 0 scrimmage that our bumpers won’t pass inspection with the pool noodles we have been using in the past. So I went on a foam finding expedition…and found two that I think are suitable, when combined, at local stores.

First is a folding exercise mat from Walmart (I think Target also sells them). It contains 1.5" thick white polyethylene  closed cell foam (as best I can tell), in 4 pieces just under 18" x 24". We took out one piece, and cut it into 4.75" wide strips, using a band saw

foam01 606×517 120 KB

foam01 606×517 120 KB

foam01 606×517 120 KB

Second is a floor tile exercise mat from Target, containing 4 pieces 24" x 24" x 0.75" thick EVA foam. We’ll play with this today, and see if we can cut it into strips, and see about assembling the two layers of different thickness and type foams, to make a nice bumper, of the correct thickness.

foam02 827×661 188 KB

foam02 827×661 188 KB

foam02 827×661 188 KB

This is quite an ordeal, I hope other teams aren’t spending nearly as much time trying to figure this out.

Waiting eagerly for vendors to start selling a nice 2.5" x 5" wide closed cell foam extrusion…

posts.name: Rich Jr
posts.cooked:
MrForbes:

our bumpers won’t pass inspection with the pool noodles we have been using in the past.

I’m curious what they told you, the noodles should still be legal.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271

posts.name: Jim Forbes
posts.cooked:
The checklist shows that we need more than 2.0" thickness of padding, and measuring the pool noodles shows they are not quite that thick. They “flatten”, and end up being too small.

Perhaps the noodles we have been using (Big Joe from Walmart) are not what other teams use, but they’re what’s available locally for a reasonable price.

posts.name: Jim Forbes
posts.cooked:
Before getting too far along, we weighed the open cell PE foam that I had found, and it’s too light, less than 1 lb per cf. So we’ll use only the EVA foam, I’ll go buy three more sets of tiles (if they have them) and we can finish the bumpers. But we’ll probably also make some new backing from 1/2" plywood, because of some issues with our attaching hardware, and missing the required backing height from the floor.

I expect that by the end of March, our competition season might be over and we won’t have to deal with bumpers for a little while. That will be nice.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Tom_Line:

Foam Factory in Michigan.

We are down the street from here, absolutely great service, even as a walk in we got exactly what we needed, and for cheap. Definitely second this as a good source
